description.text: A camera slide (or mini-dolly). Test footage can be found at https://vimeo.com/46572121

If you have a heavy camera (or lens), you will probably want to increase the value of foot_spacing (look in camera_slide_end.scad). Print 1x slide and 2x end
Add 4x LME8UU linear bearings to the carriage
Use a 1/4 inch screw to attach a camera (or quick release plate) to the carriage
Push 2x 8mm diameter rods through the bearings
Push or hammer the ends on the rods

comments.text: I think it is worth noting, that the LEM8UU bearings REQUIRE "Linear motion" rods to use in this slider config. All other rods will not be exactly 8mm as desired.

title: Catapult
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When assembling the catapult, I purposely made the spoon hole 1mm bigger than the post that slides into the catapult. When you put the post into place, it might be a little difficult to get it in. If it is too hard to squeeze in the catapult holes on the base, file or sand don the post just a little bit because the post should fit snugly in its holes. The two holes near the top of the catapult are for you to tie any size rubber band into (I used a Whole Foods rubber band). When you put the rubber band on the spoon, I found it better to wrap the rubber band around the spoon. If you have a hard time with figuring out how to assemble the catapult, ask me in the comments section.

When printing the 5mm post, print it with 100 percent infill so it doesn't snap.
I personally used PLA but any type of rigid filament should do the trick.

comments.text: Sorry, I forgot to add that you need to use supports only in the Catapult base. Everything else, you don't need supports.

title: OpenSCAD Projects for Junior High Teachers

description.text:
Student WorkSheets

This is a collection of worksheets (not shown in the preview above, but are in the download) for 10-14 year old students (or just CAD beginners in general, junior or senior) to get started in OpenSCAD. This is a very versatile design tool that will not only reinforce the number line and 3-D spatial concepts, but also allow the imaginative and curious students to quickly expand their design capabilities. Truly open ended!

OpenSCAD works with 3 definable geometric shapes- cubes (which can be transformed into any rectangular dimensions), cylinders (which can also be transformed into cones) and spheres, defined and positioned with a simple, but very powerful, scripting language. It incorporates functions to add and subtract the above shapes to build a project.

OpenSCAD is not a drag and drop design tool, but will provide students with Scripting/Programming experience, mathematics (Number Planes, 3-D Geometry and Logic) extensions, and lead to the ability to export designs (in .stl format) ready for printing! Great learning reinforcement and the absolute answer to the student groans in Mathematics classes of "When are we ever going to use this math??" and in Science "That idea is really cool, can we build it?" and in Technology "Let's make a part to do the job". Projects can truly become interdisciplinary!!

The work sheets have an extremely simple introductory project, "The microphone", then two easier projects, followed by the "Table and Chair" and the "Cricket Set". Slightly harder are the "Coffee Cup" and "Toy Cars". However these sheets can obviously be changed/overhauled to suit a particular teacher's program (files are in OpenOffice format), and indeed the whole unit can be rewritten and adapted as required. Adults who maybe a bit rusty with their mathematics, may find even their appreciation of the beauty of mathematics is rekindled! Mine was!

Enjoy!!!

OpenSCAD Scripting

OpenSCAD is a free,open-source design tool powered by a scripting language. It is very simple to do basic things with it, but has heaps of functions and tools for more advanced users. Lots of scope to challenge your brighter students, but easy enough to hand out in a mixed ability classroom. This touches base with nearly all STEM style objectives.

One quirky feature is how it uses variables. Even though it has many of the most desirable programming structures of a higher level language (branching, iteration and modularisation), any variables can only be defined once, and then they keep their value. So simple things, like X=5 then X=X+1, does not work because it implies a subsequent alteration of X's value. This is a trap for experienced programmers who do not read the fine print. However it is easy to work within this limitation for nearly all projects.

More importantly, it does handle full blown recursion and many mathematical functions, which is a big test for for most languages. Putting one or two small hindrances aside, the OpenSCAD tool is a marvellous application and a credit to the people who designed it, and now maintain it. Being free and open-source means students can have copies of OpenSCAD on all their computers at school and home. Homework and extension work is easily facilitated. Many thanks folks!!

print_settings.Notes:: Print with 3 perimeters and at least 1mm bottom and top shells. For the large parts, the only support needed is the one from the build plate (i.e. not in the horizontal drill holes). For the locks, you should either print them in PET or Nylon (for they have great layer adhesion) or turn them 90° so the "T" shape is flat on the print bed (for additional strength). The locks need support in any orientation you'll print them in.

title: Saitek X52 Pro Hotas Ikea Poäng Holder

description.text:
This mount fixes a Logitech / Saitek X52 or X52 Pro onto the armrests of an Ikea Poäng chair. Mounted with standard M5 screws and nuts - two for each hinge and three for each clamp - and with two holes for a zip-tie to organize the cables neatly.

The Stick and Throttle are mounted with the locks where the suction cups would normally go, so each one of them is locked to the base plate in four places for a sturdy mount.

Printer:

Non Sucking 3D Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,3mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print with 3 perimeters and at least 1mm bottom and top shells. For the large parts, the only support needed is the one from the build plate (i.e. not in the horizontal drill holes). For the locks, you should either print them in PET or Nylon (for they have great layer adhesion) or turn them 90° so the "T" shape is flat on the print bed (for additional strength). The locks need support in any orientation you'll print them in.

Remove support structures, assemble using standard M5 screws (30mm for hinges, 35mm for vertical) and nuts (I use hex/inbus screws from the local hardware store), mount the stick and throttle to their base plates, then mount the assembled units to the armrests. Don't over-tighten the screws. As soon as the mounts are not slipping on the armrests anymore, it is tight enough.

I designed a base plate roughly the shape and size of the HOTAS bases, measured the offsets for the locks in the bottom and did a test print, 2 layers high. Verified the locks are in the correct position and then designed the hinge and flap to be mounted on the hinge. Very basic design, it's not more than a few blocks and cylinders, actually.

description.text:
This is a remix of the rubber band PCB vice by Delph27. The main changes are in the base, which has been rounded to help resist warping. It's also got some new cutouts to reduce print time and material, as well as a tightened up channel which should be easier to print on machines which aren't great with overhangs.

The jaws are identical to the originals except for the addition of a little notch to help hold the PCB.

These parts are compatible with the original, so you can use my base with the Delph27's jaws or vice-versa, you can.

Designed from a 2D Sketch Imported into OnShape

I used a 2D paper image and scanned it to an image. I could then import this into an OnShape sketch and use a sequence of lines and arcs to get the shape of the turtle. I designed one side and then mirrored the extrusion to get a symmetrical shape along the long axis. The solid extrusion could then be shelled out to make the cutter.

description.text:
So my daughter turned 3 and she loves tools and "fixing things" (aka taking apart everything)

So I made this simple box, fastened shut with 16mm nuts on m10 studs.
If you need the stud or the nut, they are made to actual m10/16mm specs.

Closed it up with one of her favorite little blind toys, and left the wrench nearby...

The outer dimensions of the box are 76mm cubed,
It will fit something about 46W x 46D x 64H inside the posts, 
with extra room between them.

I feel like this would be a fun thing to remix with the mario question block or something...

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 (.6 nozzle)

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Made to print without supports, and real working threads/wrench.

After watching my kiddo open it, I could see making the lid stronger to prevent flex,
and with slightly more fitup in the holes in the lid,
to make it easier to remove once the nuts are taken off.

I left some room under the lid where the stud is on purpose, but i can actually see this being a problem for over-tightening creating stress in that area but alas.

comments.text: The nuts were a little big, I reprinted them at 98% and they worked perfectly. Thanks for a great box!

Non printed components:

  • 2 micro servos
  • Raspberry Pi Zero W
  • Raspberry Pi Camera Module

Octoprint Installation:

The first thing you need to do, is to install octoprint. Once installed and running, click on the gear then click on the plugin manager. Once in the plugin manager, you want to install from a URL. The URL is listed below:
https://github.com/Salandora/OctoPrint-PanTilt
Once the plugin is installed, there are a few more steps to getting the plugin to work. The first thing you need to do is connect to your raspberry pi in a putty session. To do this, open putty and type the IP Address of your raspberry pi into the hostname box. You can then start the session by clicking open. It will then ask you for your raspberry pi's username and password. By default the username is "pi" and the password is "raspberry". Once you are logged into the session, we need to run the following commands.
wget abyz.co.uk/rpi/pigpio/pigpio.zip
unzip pigpio.zip
cd PIGPIO
make
sudo make install
sudo cp pigpiod /etc/init.d/pigpiod
sudo chmod +x /etc/init.d/pigpiod
sudo update-rc.d pigpiod defaults
sudo service pigpiod start

author: Jbyrnes

title: Bullbar Camera Mount for GoPro and Other Action Cameras Truck Bull Bar Bracket 3"

description.text:
We are slowly releasing all of the designs for our 360 rigs and related products here on Thingiverse -- we have sold many but the market is slowing down for 360 rigs while our threaded inserts used in them are getting more and more popular. We hope releasing the STL files freely will encourage greater adoption of our designs, and we intend to continue supplying the inserts for the long term, and the COTS components for at least the medium term.

This is a 3" "bull bar" (the D shaped bar people put on trucks, shown in the pictures) mount for a GoPro, or similar camera. It separates into two halves, which are joined on one end by a "puzzle piece" style joint, and the other end uses M5 machine screws and 2 M5 threaded heat-set inserts, which are inserted from the opposite side for an extra-strong grip.

We ship these to customers with a strip of rubber gasket material to go between the bull bar and the mount itself to ensure a snug fit. You can use neoprene or similar drawer or toolbox liner - there is a Husky version at home depot (near the truck tool box / towing section) that is very good, and the harbor freight version works well also and is much cheaper. The harbor freight version is probably about 1/3 the thickness, which is good or bad depending on the actual diameter of your bull bar.

I drove the entire Dalton Highway (Alaska - Ice Road Truckers) in the summer time (Its an extremely rough drive without snow/ice to smooth out the road) as well as many other long drives over Alaska and Canada's roughest roads without a single problem - with an extended battery attached to the camera. I was a bit nervous about this mount when I designed it, but it has absolutely proven itself and customers around the world are using it without a single problem reported.

Printed in ABS with fairly heavy infill - especially the puzzle piece portion you want to print your ABS hot and heavy.

Only problem - uncoated ABS will discolor over a year or so. It is almost time for me to print a new one because my black filament has turned gray. There are probably coatings or other filaments that should be considered, but no big deal. ABS is up to the job.

You will need a few sizes of of threaded inserts -- which is now our primary product line.
These are available on both eBay and Amazon.
The 2 halves use M5 (short) inserts, inserted from the opposite side of the screws (so that the force of the screws pulls the inserts into the plastic rather than out. The camera mount uses #6-32(short) inserts.
Our eBay listings are here:
http://stores.ebay.com/Albers-LLC?_dmd=2&_nkw=inserts
while our Amazon listings can be found by searching for "initeq inserts"

description.text:
My boat has a cheap PiranaMAX 150 LCD depth sounder by Humminbird. A few months ago on a bad launch during rough weather, the transducer mount struck the concrete boat ramp. Needless to say, it broke away from the boat. I tried gluing it back together, with limited success. Since then, I have purchased my 3D printer and whilst out fishing a few days ago watching it flail around behind the boat, the genius penny dropped to make my own! Actually, no it didn't. The first thing was to spend 3 hours searching for a 3D model to print, alas there were none. So here we are.

Replacement brackets are quite expensive at AUD$51, when I factor in that the initial purchase cost of the ENTIRE sounder kit was only AUD$65!!

I'm currently printing out the "Prototype" mount to see how it fits. I say prototype, because I forgot to add the nut recesses and found a few hollow areas whilst printing. This newer version should work just fine. It will also be a lot stronger than the original Humminbird mount, as I have added an extra support leg where my original one let go. They also used really thin hollow plastic. I am still using all the other mounting hardware.

I printed in PLA with a BRIM, as my printer is not the best when the airconditioning system is running, likes to curl everything.
I also used supports, but it only filled the main bolt holes so unnecessary.
25% infill, entirely up to you. My 15HP motor won't break that off with the water drag :)
Used about 10100mm of filament.

This thing was made (badly) with Tinkercad. Feel free to edit it to fit your sounder at:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4k4Xy3a3c6i

title: Oahu picture frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a picture frame that forms the Hawaiian island, Oahu.

This model requires printing the front and the back part of the frame and glue them together. The transparent part can be printed or laser cut from glass or plexi.

Files:
Oahu frame front.stl: The frontal part of the frame that holds the glass.
Oahu frame back.stl: The back part of the frame that supports the frontal part.
Oahu frame glass.*: The outline for the transparent (glass or plexi) part in various format for laser cut.
Oahu frame whole.stl: The complete model assembled, not for printing, just for preview.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Rotate the back part to lay flat on your print bed before printing.

Making the transparent part

Because I have not seen a completely transparent filament, I recommend laser cutting the photo holder part from glass or plexi.

You will need two pieces with the total of 8 mm thickness:
A 3 mm thick part serves as the back holder of the photo.
A 5 mm thick part comes in front of the photo.

Assembling the parts

After printing the back and front parts, you have to glue them together. Because both parts has a 10 degree overhang which may not be printed perfectly, it is possible that the two parts will not fit perfectly at first (happened with my printer). In that case you have to sand the parts before gluing. I recommend using a gel glue.

The transparent parts are pushed from the front to their place, with the photo between them. They don't need any glue, the puzzle-like shape of the Pearl Harbor bay just keeps them in place, so you can change the photo any time later.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was inspired to create this thing when I noticed that PartsExpress had a number of TV speakers in their buyout section (Jan 2018). I already had two from an older TV so I created this speaker tube thing for my wife to listen to podcasts. I wanted it to be easy to print and assemble, requiring only some cheap ebay parts and 8 screws for the speakers.

note: This things takes a fair bit of plastic. While having a separate shell over the speakers is very easy to assemble, it does come at the cost of 100g+ of plastic. The total project probably weighs in at 250g. You may have noticed the classy white on off-white appearance in one of the pictures, this is due to me running our of my original white and using a another spool from a different manufacturer.

Print: layer height .2, infill 20%
I used the following parts:
lipstick style USB power Bank
3.5m audio breakout board
micro USB breakout board
PAM8403 amplifier board with potentiometer
2x speaker drivers 30mmx96mm. The cut out is 25mmx90mm.

On the Blank version with no speaker cutouts the mountable space is 100mmx80mm.

The input board and audio jack were mounted with nothing but hot glue. The PAM8403 was secured with the nut on its potentiometer. This thing sounds fine but lacks in bass. I added a 4.5 x .5 inch port based upon some crude calculations of internal volume. It helps but don't expect much below 120hz with TV drivers. The audio is crisp and loud and excellent for its purpose. I need to calculate the internal volume more accurately and adjust the port to remove the 180 degree bend and adjust the length more precisely. I noticed whistling/noise from the micro USB hole and the screw threads. To resolve this I used a bit more glue on the USB port and pipe dope (for plastic) on the threads.

Of course the design works as is, but could use improvements.

  • a bit more thread on the caps and speaker body
  • the speaker shell/body should have a notch to keep proper alignment

02/2018- Added new shells and shrunk the shell/body spacing. Originally I made the shell to be a 1mm interior diameter larger than the body but this was too much slop. I reduced the size to .6mm and it works better now (more snug).

No

No

.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Speaker body has to be printed in the orientation shown.

title: 2014 Genesis Coupe Shift Knob for OEM Shifter

description.text: This is part fits the OEM shifter for the 2014 Hyundai Genesis Coupe. I'm not sure if it fits the previous generation, let me know in the comments if you try it out. You'll need an M3 nut and an M3 X 6mm socket head cap screw to secure the shift knob.The nut is inserted into the slot in the bottom and held captive by the screw. I also partially filled the slot with epoxy to help keep the nut in place. I recommend using PETG, I originally tried PLA but the material is too soft and can't withstand the required torque for the cap screw.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1536561

The Piper PA-28 series is a family of single engine, low wing, four seat aircraft. PA-28's were first introduced in the 1960's, with the Piper Cherokee. It had a square wing with fixed tricycle undercarriage, and was available with engines ranging from 140 to 180 horsepower.

In the 1970's, Piper brought out a new-and-improved version of the Cherokee, known as the Warrior. The main difference between them was the wing, which was tapered half way along on the Warrior. Both the Cherokee and Warrior are popular with flying clubs and schools around the world for their simplicity and versatility.

In the late 1960's, Piper released a version of the Cherokee with retractable undercarriage and more power, named the Arrow, which later incorporated the same changes as the Warrior.

The "PA" in PA-28 stands for Piper Aircraft.

This model is designed to have the windows, wheels and propeller printed separately and in a different colour from the fuselage.

Refined models uploaded
Windows rescaled
Fuselages cut into pieces for Simplify3D
Landing gear tweaked
Spinner removed
Space for lead weight added

2018.01.19- added an updated version with a light bar to hold an led strip to provide better lighting- my strip was on the top of the printer pointing down but this new location will provide better lighting. The light bar can be attached with some thick ca.

2018.02.02- slight modification - the camera is offset in the 170, so the Logitech_C170CamMount_w_light_barOffsetCam.stl version offsets the mount placing the camera in the center giving full left to right coverage of the bed.

2018.02.09- added a diffuser for the led strip- it just slips over the led strip from above. I printed it in white.

title: SpeedHoop Embroidery Hoop
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a (probably) new take on the old concept of an embroidery hoop. Rather than a split outer hoop, this one works with a 5-start tapered thread. To use it, the cloth is draped over the lower part, then the top part is screwed on. Since it's a 5-start thread (pentuple helix), it only takes about a 30 degree twist to jam the parts together, clamping the cloth in place. Even for a fumbling non-fiber-arty engineer like me, I can do this in about 5 seconds. This also may be useful to people with dexterity problems due to arthritis or similar issues because it is way less fiddly than the traditional design.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

25%, 3 outer layers

Notes:

It prints well in PLA without supports, and also is amenable to being scaled up or down in size if the printer can cope with it. Note that there are some bevels that don't like being scaled up, so if you want to do a (say) 160% size version, you should print with supports.

Finishing

A little hand sanding to clean up any sharp edges or nubby bits is a good idea so it doesn't snag cloth.

Thought process

My wife, Gina, wanted an embroidery hoop. This design came to me in a flash, I can't really say exactly how I figured it out -- the very initial idea was to use a tapered thread so that it can jam onto cloth of arbitrary thickness, holding it evenly without damage.

description.text:
Here is the minimalist of gun cabinet organizers. Designed at 15mm for Glock and other polymer lowers with wider trigger grips, these slide-together puzzle pieces included some glue-in spacers which allow it to work down to my little Browning .22 1911 which has a trigger guard of 8mm. Take that 5mm spacer and in your printing software, turn off uniform scaling and adjust the width to whatever you want! For 1911's and long barrel guns, you may want to elevate it by mounting it to a piece of wood or simply printing a base. It fit all of my guns including the full size 1911 but it didn't hold on to much. but it really doesn't need to.

I printed 3 spacers on the bed at the same time. One at 4mm, one at 5mm and one at 6mm.

remixed_from.author: Kenny4842
remixed_from.title: Modular Thomas the train trackmaster rail car wagons

description.text:
This is a mashup (meshup?) between the modular trackmaster trucks and a realish train caboose. I simplified the model of the caboose in an attempt to make it more toddler-resistant. I combined the "flat car" mesh from the modular trucks directly into the caboose mesh.

Print the body, undercarriage, and roofs with a brim to keep edges flat, but the smaller pieces without a brim to keep their shape.

The wheel and body holes and pegs may need sanding to allow the pegs to fit in the undercarriage and the wheels to turn smoothly.

I glued the roofs to the body and the body to the undercarriage with superglue. But if you had a tight enough fit on the undercarriage pegs, you could try just using press fit.

I painted the roof and wheels with black (spraypaint), and the body with red. Of course they could have been printed in that color to begin with, but all I had at the time was white. :)

After finishing this and seeing it with the other cars, it sticks out a bit due to the raised undercarriage. The manufactured cars have wheels sunk into the undercarriage and those look better. At some point I may try to design a simple undercarriage like that.

The camera was from https://www.getfpv.com/fx805-micro-fpv-camera-5-8ghz-37ch-25mw-vtx-with-mounting-case.html

V5 was created to be printed in SLS Nylon. I've it sent off to 3dhubs.com and the results were awesome! V5 is probably not a great print with FDM due to the elevated base, but let me know if it works out for you. V5 should remove the need for spacers and extra nuts to secure the mount to the quad, if you use an m2 tap to add threads.

And of course a big thanks to fishpepper: http://fishpepper.de/2017/07/28/how-to-build-a-2s-pepperfiish-beast-shopping-list-recommendations/

Version Notes:
V1's fitting was too tight.
V2 was pretty good, but the roll cage was way too tiny.
V3 adds a .5mm offset on the rear rib to place my polou vreg, it raises the cam box a bit, and it beef up the roll cage a lot. V3's fit was good, but the camera box was a tad too deep.
V4 shrinks the camera box depth by .2mm, shifts the angle supports, and adds a hole to save weight. V4 had a better (snug) fit on the camera, and is .2g lighter than V3.

description.text:
I created this wine rack after watching Joe Telling(3d Printing Nerd https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2744127) printing his wine rack, while looking cool, I thought it was a lot of plastic and wanted something a bit more minimalist and conservative on plastic, using it's structure for strength.
The only way to own one of these is if it is 3d printed.
I also wanted no clean up nor gluing and assembly.
The 3 bottle unit weighs 285 grams and about 20 hours to print.
The 6 bottle unit weighs in at 550 grams
The 8 bottle unit is approx 725 grams.
They don't require any assembly.
The continuous loops top and bottom gives it intrinsic strength, while the open artistic body provides appealing lines even when empty(heaven forbid).
It also is symmetrical so will look good from both sides sitting on a table.
Will hold up to a 90 mm bottle diameter(std wine rack size).
While this model only holds six bottles, I am working on a clip system that will enable almost endless combinations.
I also created it to fit on a 300x300 print bed however have created one in the that will fit on a 200x200 bed but will be more useful when the clip system is complete, but should look nice with 3 bottles on a coffee table.

Before I release the clip system, I want to be at home and test the process myself, in the meantime I believe this should be fun to start with.

Disclaimer: I have not printed this yet as I am overseas for a month and don't have access to my printer, but still enjoy the design work. It predicts about a 40 hour print time for the 6 bottle unit and 52 hours for the 8 bottle unit with 3 top and bottom layers and 2 perimeters and 20% fill in Simplify 3d.

I created this to print on my CR 10 primarily, however anyone with a 300 X 300 print be will be fine. The 3 bottle unit should print on most beds that have a 200mm bed.

title: Weighted Base for Modular Clamping System

description.text:
This is a weighted base that hold clamps and other tools in various configurations so that you can saw/ file/ airbrush model parts. It is also a container for useless currency (US and Canadian pennies). It holds a dollar's worth. In some post-apocalyptic future, when desperate mobs scour the landscape for copper, it could be a source of hidden wealth.

The system works nicely in the sense that, when you get things dialed in right, the pieces snap together like Lego bricks. Small No. 0 wood screws fit into sockets in the bases of the various modular pieces. The screw collars push the walls of the sockets outwards. By tightening the screws and filing the outside edges of the sockets, you can get a solid fit into the holes in the base. If the contact wears and becomes loose over time, just tighten down the screws a bit further.

Here is a list of tools that you can use with this thing. I'll add more soon. I'm open to further suggestions:

  • Small Clamp for Modular Clamping System
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2762270
  • Clothespin Mini Claps
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2780436
  • Airbrush Stand
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2778564

If there's is any interest, I could make a version for the Euro 5 cent piece, or the British penny.

To assemble: fill with pennies and screw together with four No. 0 (4 x 1/2) wood screws--don't overtighten. Add the non-slip feet of your choice to the bottom surface. I use the generic "No Slip Stoppers" shown in photo 2.

Updates:

  • Feb 3/18 - This was updated so that the edges are of equal length. The coin sockets are now evenly space. Height was reduced in height by 1.35 mm.

title: O'Cello for 1/2" rod, folding chest rest, telescoping knee rest

description.text:
This is o'cello with 1/2" center rod ( 13mm-ish hole ).

First thanks cokane for the excellent model, I own a electric one but it is rather bulky, and I try to make a compact one in this build.

I used these items:
tube (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000H9K3D8/)
rod (https://www.homedepot.com/p/1-4-in-x-36-in-Zinc-Plated-Round-Rod-802297/204273961)
to make the telescoping end pin.
Rubber end pin tip (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B075R8PSVS) is used as even ninjaflex is not as grippy as the real rubber tip.

In this build I also made a different part 6 to mount a c-channel holder, which holds two c-channel style shelve stiffener for a telescoping knee brace. The c-channel I have is for 3/4" board.. but I can't find web page for it. So you might need to modify those parts to fit your need.

The tuner I got (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GGMWD3S) is 14mm in diameter, and I made a version of part 6 to hold it without a screw plug. I printed part 6 with 4 layer wall, and it is holding up fine.

Yet another piece in this build is a folding chest rest, which should also work for normal 12mm build.

For the hand screw style hardware, I use 1/4 hex screw and wing nuts. the rest are the same m5 socket screws, some might be shorter. This assorted screw
(https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072LTK9S8/) is what I got, so if you get it you are covered.

Now on to playing cello! I need some better string now!

P.S. Somehow Thingiverse is killing my amazon links when they add their affiliate tags. Copy and paste the URL to view the item.

Floating a seed in a cradle like this is better than the conventional toothpick method because it allows for the seed to stay at a consistent water level because it moves with the water as it evaporates or is consumed by the plant. This removes the need for you to constantly watch and refill the water level for the seed.

Note: The smaller the vessel its in, the Water will need to be changed more regularly. As with any method of seed starting, this is not really avoidable. It is essential that you do this to avoid mold or fouled water.

This is designed to float an Avocado seed in water to allow it to sprout and grow before transplanting it. This works for my avocado seeds but if it doesn't work for you, you may need to scale it up for added buoyancy if you have a larger than typical avocado seed.

I set the scale to 5.3 for my avocado seed. (scaling fixed in update)

tool tray

A rought but pretty close reproduction of the vents from the 1989 Transformers Mega Pretender Crossblades.

Owning this toy, but missing the two pods, I wanted something that'll look the part. With only a few very iffy photos, i went about trying to recreate this part. While appearing right and correct, the size might be slighty off and the shape might be a bit off if you have the real thing in front of you, a luxuy I did not have.

It's basiclly symetrical so to make either left or right, just print it. If you need both, print it twice, but you might wish to mirror it

I recommend supports but they might not be needed depending on alignment on the printer bed. The official colour is a shade of tan which I don't have, but a touch of paint does the job well enough. Also included in this is my own repro of the sticker. It's not scaled so you will need to do that yourself, and like the model, flip to do the other side.

Also works with Blue Bacchus, who was a retool of Crossblades.

title: Belted Extruder v4 - 2.85mm / 3mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Belted Extruder v4 - 2.85mm / 3mm

The Belted Extruder v4 is a Geared Extruder using a GT2 Belt and Aluminium Pulleys for optiomal accuracy, resolution and power.
The BEv4 is an updated version of my Belted Extruder V3. The v3 uses larger more "standard" bearings.

This model is for 2.85mm / 3mm filaments. You can find the Belted Extruder V4, 1.75mm here.

Proven record
I've been using the v3-4 for over a year and it's an extremely reliable design. My first one printed in PLA is still running!
Aside from countless users, I also know of several companies using these for their printer-farms by now, as they are very cheap to deploy and requires close to no maintenance.

What is a Belted Extruder and why is it build using Aluminium Pulleys?

  • It is a geared extruder
  • It uses 2 aluminium pulleys and a belt to drive the filament drivebit
  • Silent running due to belt usage
  • Higher accuracy and longelevity due to aluminium pulleys vs printed
  • Design of printed parts to achieve rigidity and stability
  • No hard to print gears which degrade and loose accuracy
  • All parts used are readily available, so not forcing you to buy key components from me
  • It measures 90mm by 52mm.

Printer:

CrossBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

70%

Notes:
  • I printed using a 0.4mm Nozzle
  • I printed using 3 perimeters/borders - Do not print with 1 or 2 perimeters
  • The main Extruder part and Idler must have 50-70% infill depending on material used.
  • Use a strong infill. Not a type which only print every other layer
  • Used 4 top/bottom layers. Meanig 0.8mm each
  • Idler can print as body. All other parts is printed with 100% infill - important
  • The 2x8mmSpacer is printed 2 times, while all other parts are printed 1 time each

Bill of Material (BOM)
  • 1x 60-GT2 aluminium pulley
  • 1x 16-GT2 Pulley for the small gear, which gives a ratio of 1:3.75 - you can use a 20-GT2 pulley for 1:3 ratio
  • Strongly advice you to buy the Hobb-Goblin - 8mm Hobbed Shaft Kit from E3D - you can also buy it from Filastruder if that is easier for you.
    All necessary nuts and spacers for the filamentdrive assembly are included when buying these
  • 2x Bowden Couplers for 3mm filament. I'm using the standard Ultimaker 2 couplers for Bowden with 6.4mm OD
  • 172-GT2 Belt needed - 172mm/86 teeth
  • A Nema 17 motor- I'm using the super nice 09. degree 17HM19-2004S - The pancakge model is not powerfull enough for 3mm filaments
  • 3x 688 bearings. 8x16x5 - Type doesn't matter.
  • 1x m3 25mm Rounded Head screw - for Idler
  • 1x m3 15mm Rounded Head screw - for Idler bearing
  • 1x m3 40mm Partially Threaded Socket Head screw - for Tightener
  • 1x 10mm steel spring - for Tightener
  • 6x m3 nuts
  • 4x m3 Rounded Head screw - for motor
  • 4x m3 spacers - for motor

title: Pimote - Home Assistant Dashboard remote / Télécommande

description.text:
English

This is a Raspberry Pi Zero based remote control for Home Assistant and HADashboard.
https://home-assistant.io
https://home-assistant.io/docs/ecosystem/hadashboard

No screw, no glue, just fun !

UPDATE:
New working lpwd.py script. Now shutdown when low battery works correctly.

Français

Télécommande à base de Raspberry Pi Zero pour la solution domotique Home Assistant et HADashboard.
https://home-assistant.io
https://home-assistant.io/docs/ecosystem/hadashboard

Ni clous ni vis, Nicole !

Mise à jour:
Nouveau script python lpwd.py. L'arrêt propre du Pi en cas de batterie faible fonctionne dorénavant.

Printer:

Dagoma Discovery 200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

0 - 20%

Notes:

English

  • Use brim.
  • First layer: 0.2mm
  • All other layers: 0.15mm
  • Infill can be set at 0% (see below) or a normal 20%
  • Wall thickness 0.8mm - 1.2mm with an extruder size of 0.4mm

You can set infill to 0% and wall thickness to 1.2mm. This is usefull if, like me, you use some transparent filament at the led level. These are more easily viewable. Also, these settings provide a strong enough case.

For a multilayer print, I used the following measures to pause my printer, from bottom to top:

  • 5.6mm
  • 8.6mm
  • 25.4mm
  • 28.4mm

The total height of the case is 34mm.

Français

  • Utilisez un brim.
  • Première couche: 0.2mm
  • Autres couches: 0.15mm
  • Remplissage possible à 0% (voir plus bas) ou un taux normal de 20%
  • Épaisseur des cloisons 0.8mm - 1.2mm avec un diamètre de buse de 0.4mm

Vous pouvez régler le remplissage à 0% et l'épaisseur des cloisons à 1.2mm. Cela est utile si, comme moi, vous utilisez du filament transparent au niveau des leds. Ces dernières seront alors bien visible. Aussi, ces réglages permettent d'avoir un boîtier suffisamment solide.

Pour une impression multi couches, vous pouvez vous baser sur les mesures suivantes. Du bas vers le haut:

  • 5.6mm
  • 8.6mm
  • 25.4mm
  • 28.4mm

La hauteur total du boîtier est de 34mm.

Parts / Assembly - English

Part list

  • Raspberry Pi Zero WH
  • 3.5" Raspberry Pi 1 Touchscreen
  • Adafruit 1000C Powerboost
  • MPU 6050 Accelerometer
  • Slide switch
  • 3.7V Lithium Polymer battery 2500 mah. 60mmX50mmX8mm

Assembly

Slide Switch

The slide switch is very tricky to put in place. I highly recommand to solder it AFTER having it inserted in the case.
Be aware that this is a one shot. It is almost impossible to remove it from the case when in place without destroying it (I used 3 of them).
On the other hand, it holds quite firmly and will stick at its position forever.
Solder Powerboost EN pin and GND pin to the switch. More info on Adafruit website or check the Fritzing schema provided.

Touchscreen

I decided to use specifically the Adafruit 3.5" Touchscreen for Raspberyy PI 1 because the PCB overhangs by 5mm the Pi. It allows me to have a wider part at the bottom of the case. Also, this TFT screen is dimmable and, of course, it can be powered down to save battery. By the way, the autonomy is about 7h.

Accelerometer

The screen lights up thanks to the accelerometer. When the Pimote is taken in hand or moved, this will dimm up the backlight. To avoid the screen to turn off, hold it in any position except horizontal one. In this last case, it will dimm half down after 5s, then turn off completely after another 5s.
The provided C file "motion_detect2.c" is the program responsible for this behaviour.
To compile this program, issue the command:
gcc -o motion_detect2 motion_detect2.c -lwiringPi -lm

More information here:
http://www.pibits.net/code/raspberry-pi-mpu-6050-c-example.php

Powerboost

The pin LBO (low battery output) from the Adafruit Powerboost is connected to the Pi GPIO header, pin 17. I also provide a Python script (lpwd.py) which, if running in background, will cleanly shutdown the Pi when battery voltage drops down too much (well actually, this doesn't work for me on this project. Still debugging).

Home Assistant and HADashboard

Of course you will need a running Home Assistant server with a HADashboard. I will not explain how to set this up as it's quite out of scope here. If you're interested in these great automation tools please have a look on the websites referenced in the summary

Miscelaneous Raspbian things

You will have to use a full Rabian Stretch image which include a LXDE desktop.
You will have to configure the Pi to boot the graphical environment with an autologin, usually the pi user is chosen.

I tried various web browser. I found the best one is Iceweasel (Firefox ESR). I had to use some tricks to set it in full screen mode and disable mouse pointer. To achieve that, I used these two tools:

  • xdotools
  • unclutter

I won't develop more this part but feel free to contact me if you need some help on this, or other, points. I'll be glad to answer you.

Pièces / Assemblage - Français

Liste des pièces

  • Raspberry Pi Zero WH
  • Ecran tactile 3.5" pour Raspberry Pi 1 (un)
  • Adafruit 1000C Powerboost
  • MPU 6050 Accéléromètre / gyroscope
  • Petits interrupteurs à glissière
  • Batterie Lithium Polymère 3.7V 2500 mah. 60mmX50mmX8mm

Assemblage

Interrupteur

L'interrupteur est particulièrement difficile à mettre en place. Je vous recommande vivement de le souder APRÈS l'avoir inséré dans le boîtier. Sachez que vous n'aurez qu'un seul essai. Il est quasiment impossible d'enlever l'interrupteur sans le détruire (j'en ai utilisé 3).
D'un autre côté, une fois en place, ce dernier tient parfaitement bien, sans jeux.
Soudez les pin EN et GND du Powerboost aux pins de l'interrupteur (pin 1,2 ou 2,3 mais PAS 1,3). Plus d'info sur le site d'Adafruit ou consultez le schema Fritzing fourni.

Écran tactile

J'ai choisi l'écran tactile Adafruit 3,5 pouces pour Raspberry Pi 1. Le Pi va du coup dépasser de quelques mm par rapport au bord de l'écran. Cela permet d'avoir une zone un peu plus large pour le couvercle du boîtier; Esthétiquement, j'ai préféré.
Cet écran dispose également d'un rétro éclairage variable grâce à la pin 18 du GPIO du Pi. Ce dernier peut donc aussi être totalement coupé pour préserver la batterie. L'autonomie de cette dernière est d'environ 7h.

Accéléromètre / gyroscope

L'écran s'allume grâce à ce composant. Quand le Pimote est pris en main ou déplacé, le rétro éclairage va rapidement et progressivement s'illuminer. Pour éviter qu'il s'éteigne, il suffit de le garder dans une position non horizontale. S'il est posé à plat, la luminosité de l'écran va baisser à 30% après 5s puis s'éteindre complètement après 5 autres secondes.
Le programme C fourni "motion_detect2.c" est responsable de ce comportement.
Pour le compiler, utilisez la commande suivante:
gcc -o motion_detect2 motion_detect2.c -lwiringPi -lm

Plus d'information là:
http://www.pibits.net/code/raspberry-pi-mpu-6050-c-example.php

Powerboost

La pin LBO (low battery output ou Fini batterie) est connectée à la pin 17 du GPIO du Pi. Je fourni aussi un script Python 'lpwd.py) qui, lorsqu'il tourne en tâche de fond, va proprement arrêté le Pi si la tension de la batterie est trop basse avant que le Powerboost coupe le courant (bon en fait ça marche pas chez moi pour ce projet. Je suis toujours en train de débugguer le truc).

Home Assistant et HADashboard

Vous aurez bien entendu besoin d'un serveur Home Assistant et d'un HADashboard qui va avec. Je ne vais pas expliquer ici comment installer ou configurer ces applications car hors sujet. Je vous invite en revanche à suivre les liens indiqués dans le résumé (en haut) de cette description.

Configuration du système

Vous aurez besoin d'une image de Raspbian Full c'est à dire avec un environnement graphique, type LXDE.
Il vous faudra configurer votre Pi pour démarrer automatiquement dans cet environnement avec un login automatique, généralement avec l'utilisateur "pi".

J'ai essayé de nombreux navigateurs Internet. Celui qui me convient le plus est Iceweasel (Firefox ESR). J'ai configuré un profil particulier pour ce dernier (safe mode, zoom, pas de restoration des onglets précédents...).
J'ai aussi eu besoin de ces 2 utilitaires:

  • xdotools
  • unclutter

Je ne m'étendrai pas sur tous les trucs et astuces auxquels j'ai eu recours mais n'hésitez pas à me contacter si vous avez besoin de plus d'info, je serais heureux de vous répondre (tutoiement obligatoire hein ?!).
Merci d'avoir lu jusque là.
PC

title: office watering can and measure cup

description.text: My beautiful, small watering cans (measure cups) for my office plants. they hold 1,5 dl (i wanted to know how much water i put in each time). The first version has marking for 1,5 dl (within one mm of the mark.), and V2 has markings for 0,5; 1,0; and 1,5 dl.

Shouldnt leak

...But if it seems to do, a drop of super glue in the leaking area should do the trick. ( I printed one that seems completely watertight, and one that squeezed out a droplet in a couple of places after holding water for many hours.

Simple and print friendly

V1 started as the simplest possible thing a could make in Siemens NX CAD software. But then, of course, i needed it to be a little more fancy and advanced. Still not surface modeling art though :-)
The bottom is 1mm thick. The large cylinder wall is 0.8mm thick, and the spout wall is approximately 1mm thick. Prints perfectly without support, and there is not much room for infill :-)

description.text:
This is a 3D-printable case for the Amazon Dash button. It's designed to be used either with the sticky pad included (and used to stick it to the inside back of the case) or you will need to use a mm thick spacer/foam pad to hold it in place. The back holds in place purely with friction as long as you don't take it off and put it on too many times. I left a bit of additional space around the outside of the dash to allow for shrinkage of different printers, so if the dash isn't stuck in with double-sided tape or similar it will rattle around.

It's ideal to stick onto a wall etc next to whatever you want to control/order. I use alternate versions at home that can hold multiple Dash buttons (see remixes) where I've cut an icon for whatever it controls into the case as I don't use them to actually order things from Amazon, but to talk to a Raspberry Pi listening for the broadcast when they connect to my network!

I created it in Solidworks and included those files as well as the STLs for printing. The case is 3.2mm thick as I found that any thinner with my printer with it's 0.4mm nozzle the inside and outside of the wall separate.

DeltaWASP 2040

title: Bungee launcher pedal - laser cut files

description.text:
Good news for RC fix wing pilots !

Here are the laser cutting files of my bad ass drones bungee launcher pedal !
It also includes 2 hooks for the aircraft and a bonus badassdrones key-chain ;)

Please note that this is meant to be cut in a 6mm thick plywood. You can then assemble the different pieces with CA glue or any wood glue.

All you need to add :

  • a 6mm diameter and ~35mm long metal or plastic cylinder (mine are made of PMMA)
  • 2 screws and bolts
  • few tent pegs or long nails to secure the pedal on the ground
  • safety pin (optional but recommended)
  • a bungee rope > strength depending on the airplane weight

Enjoy !

title: TFM 8 -  3d printed Transverse Flux Generator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Transverse flux machine (TFM) is a very interesting technology for electric motors and generators. Machines of this type work well where there are low speeds and high torque
The transverse flux technology was first described by W. M. Morday, who got patent in 1895.
In TFM generator there is only one coil inside the iron yoke. It is also possible to make a 3-phase generator.
As an electric motor TFM can be used in transport, for example, electric cars, electric bike, scooter, electro-skateboard and so on.
TFM generator can be used in wind and hydro generators. There is no need for gearboxes as the generator works at low RPM very well.
Main advantages:
-Low rotary speeds (less 1000RPM)
-High continuous torque.
-High coefficient of copper wire use.
-Low cost.
-Small size.

Printed parts are three models. This is the two body caps and the rotor.
Iron plates I cut out of electrical steel 0.5mm thick.

Shaft 8mm bearing 608 (you can pick out from old spinners)
Magnets 10X5X5mm - axial magnetization as in the pictures.

Printer:

Anet A8

Infill:

0,15

title: Pokémon TCG Energy Buttons, Special Condition Markers and more

description.text:
This is a work in progress, so these designs may get updated :) As you can see from the photos, I have already made a few different versions of the poisoned-marker for example. Theres two different designs to choose from. (Poisoned has a third level as the eyes and the nose. Poisoned2 has holes as eyes and nose.)

In my opinion, its sometimes a bit difficult to keep track on how many energys is attached to a Pokémon and what special condition moved the card upside down etc. This made me think if it would be possible to make similar energy buttons as seen in the online version of Pokémon TCG and also design totally new markers for special conditions that dont normally have a marker.

I used Selva 3D and Tinkercad to design these models. I dont have all the right colors to print everything the way I would want to so I have made some compromises.

EDIT 31.1.2018
I added a Active Pokémon -platform to hold three special condition markers, eight energy buttons and your active Pokémon :)

title: FruitPlate "The Wave" cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This fruitplate is a close relative of my Fruit Bowl "Sphere" as it shares the same design principle of interlocking pieces. Apart from the bowl I used Fusion360 to create the basic body utilizing the 'form' tool.
After burying 123-Make Autodesk released the 'Slicer' as an AddOn to Fusion360. It still could be used as a stand-alone-tool, which is no drawback as it does not work in any linked way to Fusion. You can't even update the model with the same parameters.
Same as last time I used Illustrator to nest the parts much more effective than the 'Slicer' could manage to do.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 9 mm birch plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.5 mm flute. The parts were glued to gether and oiled to give it a nice finish.

Please be aware that the stl-file is for viewing only. I haven't tried to print it, but I uploaded the 'Slicer'-sourcefile where you can export single parts to print.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

title: Z-Clip bedtime good angle phone holder

description.text:
When you lay your head on your pillow, ready to fall asleep to Netflix or Youtube, like any other normal person, your phone screen should NOT be horizontal.
The screen should be in a incline like your eyes.

Just put the Z-clip on your phone and let it stand on the Z-clip and the phones one corner.
When you want to lay your body on the other side, just move the phone to the other side of your bed and flip the phone to the other corner.

If you absolutely, for some strange reason, need to have the phones screen horizontal....
Just print out two Z-Clips. :-)

Fast and easy to print, impossible to live without :-)

The design fit my Samsung S8+ but it is easy to scale up or down to fit your phone.

I have made two versions. One straight up and one angled more back.

This LCD Controller is similar to my other design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2756990) but adds a voltmeter to the project. It also has 'snaps' to interlock bezel to base.

Controller available on Amazon Prime for around $13. Search for "12864 LCD Full Graphic Smart Display Controller". Voltmeter from Banggood.com for under $4. Search for "Geekcreit® 0.28 Inch 2.5V-30V Mini Digital Volt Meter". NOTE: you will have to move the contrast pot on the LCD Controller to the back to make room for the voltmeter. This requires basic soldering skills and tools.

Use a sharp knife to remove the thin film over the holes for the LCD controls. 3mm screws secure the LCD to the bezel. The voltmeter is secured with #2 x 1/4 thread forming screws, or you could use hot glue. The cutout in the back of the base is for the ribbon cables to exit

The example shown has bezel printed in Gun Metal Gray PLA; base in silver; reset button actuator in orange for contrast.

author: Krusven

description.text:
This is very much a work in progress. Well for a given value of progress...

I will at least update this thingiverse log with better pictures and instructions when I get a chance.

I have printed this as a working item, as you can see in the video, with some post processing as detailed on each part.

You will need:

6x Block (needs support, no real postprocessing except removing that support)
6x Conrod (print this sideways, needs support and that needs some sanding away to make a good ball joint)
6x Piston (I printed this with the top up so it needed support. Needed a bit of sanding)
2x Crank (printed standing up with support)
2x Crank mid (printed on their side with support)
3x 2 Axle (printed on end)
12x Clip (printed standing on end with support)
4x Half Clip (printed on end with support)
4x 4x1 Tall (printed standing up as normal, no support)
2x 6x1 Flat (printed standing up as normal, no support)
2x 4x1 Flat (printed standing up as normal, no support)
1x Fan (printed as modelled, shouldnt need support?)
1x Stand (printed with very low infil to save plastic, no support)

I've now added a few exploded view images which should show how the thing is put together when you have all the bits (and changed the number of axles needed!)

https://youtu.be/Qzeq3x_GwpE

Issues that I've found so far:

  • The piston to conrod ball joint is a bit stiff and produces most of the friction in the system, needs more sanding than I gave them.
  • Pistons may need shrinking a touch in diameter ...
  • Stand is huge and peels easily due to large flat first layer
  • Some of the studs don't link to the other parts as strongly as I like (I found this especially with the 4x1 Flat which has slightly larger studs now)
  • The fan ends dont have the correct castelation (is that even a word) pattern on them, they look correct but in reality have the wrong number of teeth. I couldnt get onshape to model what I wanted...

remixed_from.author: mareklew
remixed_from.title: 1610 CNC end stops / homing switches (X and Z adjustable)

title: 1610 CNC end stops / homing switches (X and Z adjustable) Modified for reprap limit switches

description.text:
What is it?
This is a set of parts needed to install end-stops on a cheap chinese 'CNC engraver' going by the name of 1610 CNC (sold in Germany via Amazon marketplace under the name of "Beautystar CNC 1610" or some similar names.

What's a 1610 CNC?
There's a couple of cheap "CNC engravers" out there, they usually go by the size of the milling area. In my case it's a "1610" which stands for 160mm x 100mm (XY). These things are quite good for what one could expect from a heap of aluminum extrusions, that is: forget it's a mill, it's a 'carver', if you go easy and slow it can chew through wood (even hardwood) without much struggling. You can get parts with quite accurate dimensions, which means: accurate for wood! 0.05mm (0.002", 2 thou) size accuracy is what we are talking about, which is much less than the wood will expand or contract with humidity. To get even this level of accuracy you have to get the assembly perfect, and this is where it really shows these aren't cnc mills: There are no independent adjustments, there's nowhere to shim spindle, forget tramming, it's all about how good are you with loosening and tightening the right bolts.

Remix from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2633933

Modified to support these limit switches...

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01FX8SR8A/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

comments.text: How did you wire the limit switches into the board?  There are 3 wires on the switch and only two pins on the board.  Also, could you post your grbl parameters?
comments.author: nathanjenny

comments.text: Cool! It seems that you've got a slightly different version of 1610 from mine - the X Carriage is injection moulded instead of being 3D printed like mine! Good to know it fits anyway :D
comments.author: mareklew

comments.text: Yeah, mine is Injection moulded. Very similar to yours, but mine wouldnt work with your Z Plunger. I had to build a new one that snaps in place. Its super snug and doesnt need bolted to the carriage.

title: Sodastream Jet Drip Tray
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Why

My colleague lost the drip tray to his Sodastream Jet machine, which was rather inconvenient. I was able to get a hold of a spare one and modeled a replacement that's tested and fits.

Features

  • Tested to fit Sodastream Jet machine (possibly others)
  • Tested with PLA and PETG, though ABS should also work.

Instructions

  • Printing it upside-down is easiest, but may leave scarring from supports inside the drip tray.
  • Use supports with ~60 degrees overhang treshold
  • FDM prints are slightly porous, but some extra perimeters and top/bottom layers should help with waterproofing.

Open Source

As always the original design file (fusion360) is included, so feel free to improve it (or learn from it)!

title: Flexible Shaft Coupler for Various Shaft Sizes

description.text:
Flexible Shaft Coupler - for several different shaft sizes:

  • 5mm shaft with flat (Common on NEMA 17 Motors)
  • 6.35mm shaft with flat (Common on NEMA 23 Motors)
  • 8mm shaft (a common size for leadscrews/ballscrews)

I hope this list can grow - I plan on adding additional shaft options as they are requested.

Print the coupler end pieces from PLA, ABS, PETG, Nylon, or any other strong, relatively non-flexible filament, and the flexible insert with NinjaFlex, TPU, or some other type of flexible material. The inset holes are designed for 4mm screws and nuts to clamp the coupler to the shafts.

Let me know if other shaft sizes/profiles are needed, I'd be happy to add them. Send me detailed measurements on the shaft diameter and any flats that may be present. Drawings or photos as reference would help immensely. I'll do my best to get any requests added within a few days of receiving them, depending on how busy I am.

Enjoy!

title: Autolevel mount for V6 delta printers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Why

This is a quick design for an autolevel probe that should fit most Delta effectors like the Anycubic Kossel, FLsun etc. etc.

The probe is specifically made to support Delta printers with effectors that clamp the top end of a bowden V6 extruder. It's probably too short for a V5 hotend.

Features

  • Fits most Delta effectors
  • Designed to match the e3d v6 hotend in length
  • Uses standard M3 mounting hardware (nut and bolts)
  • Uses standard endstop switch

Instructions

  • Print it in PETG with multiple walls and slow speed to get the strongest part.
  • Print without a fan to get the strongest part.
  • No supports required
  • If you encounter inconsistent bed leveling, your effector may not be entirely level. Mount the probe closer to the center, or upgrade to a hotend-mounted autolevel probe.

Open Source

As always the original design file (fusion360) is included, so feel free to improve it (or learn from it)!

description.text:
I like to be able to use two screens at my desk at work, so I designed this folding stand that I can stand my laptop in to give a two screen setup with my monitor.

I've made it foldable to make it smaller so that it can fit in my bag at the end of the day.

I printed it in Black PETG, after numerous warped attempts in ABS. I didn't try PLA as I didn't think that that would be strong enough.

My Dell Latitude E5450 fits nicely with the arms separated by 220mm.

To complete the stand, you'll need:

1 x LH moving arm
1 x RH moving arm
1 x LH main arm
1 x RH moving arm
2 x plugs
2 x M6 threaded rod, 250mm long
1 x M6 threaded rod, 220mm long
6 x M6 Nyloc nuts
6 x M6 washers
6 x M6 plain nuts

It's a fiddle to get it assembled and might take some sanding. It doesn't need any glue.

till a toy from late 1950s. It also suffered a complete disassembly… to install a (totally invisible) pilot in the cab! From this toy, I only have the 2 (or 3?) thread worm gear transmission and the flywheels. Casually, I began to glimpse the notion of transmission reversibility with this mechanism!

At the time, the Lille-Lesquin airport, not really overburdened, was used for training pilots. And dozens of Boeing 707 rotations passed over our heads! About noise, nothing to do with the current planes! That would be absolutely unbearable nowadays, but I don’t remember of having suffered of it. In primary school, we visited the Lesquin airport control tower. I don’t have many memories, except a word that greatly impressed me: radiogoniomètre (direction finder)!

description.text:
Deutsch:
Dies ist ein Remix des Designs von Puddlefist (siehe: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2320216)

Ich habe lediglich vorhandene Schriftzüge entfernt, da diese mit meinen Einstellungen optisch nicht besonders ansprechend werden und somit gleichzeitig Platz für einen Lüfter-Schalter geschaffen.
Somit kann der Extruderlüfter oder eine vorhandene Beleuchtung einfach abgeschaltet werden.
Weiterhin ist der Ausschnitt der Schalter so angepasst, dass keine Verschraubung mehr nötig ist.

Folgende Schalter habe ich genutzt:
Lüfterschalter: https://www.ebay.de/itm/232232643200
Hauptschalter: http://www.ebay.de/itm/222443099114
Natürlich können diese auch deutlich günstiger erworben werden.

English:
This is a remix of Puddlefists design (see: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2320216)
I removed existing lettering, as these are optically not very appealing with my settings and thus simultaneously created space for a fan switch.
Thus, the extruder-fan or existing lighting can be easily switched off.
Furthermore, the cutout of the switches is adjusted so that no screwing is necessary.

I have used the following switches:
Fan switch: https://www.ebay.de/itm/232232643200
Main switch: http://www.ebay.de/itm/222443099114
Of course, these can also be purchased much cheaper.

description.text: Spool holder made from copper pipe and aluminum tubing.  Added a few pieces of simulated leather for visual offset.  Not really steampunk, but whatever.

title: Under-mount Card Reader and USB Hub for Standing Desk

description.text:
These accessories were designed to hold in place some gadgets on the two new standing desks I built. I wanted to reduce wire clutter on the desks and run all USB connections to an under-mounted and otherwise low-profile USB hub.

I also frequently need the card reader (don't we all??) and wanted to reduce number of wires, hence the cheesy unpowered USB 3.0 splitter/hub in the middle.

Powered USB 3.0 Hub

Card Reader

USB 3.0 mini hub

USB cable Extension (Optional)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1 - .2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I suggest printing the Card Reader holder in a vertical position with the rear screw tab pointing down.

Extruder = 210 degrees
Bed = 50 degrees

The card reader holder and usb hub holder are meant to meet eachother at a central point. Because of this there's a little bit less support than necessary on one side of the USB hub - I suggest using some hot glue to firmly attach the USB Hub to the mounting bracket before install.

Card reader fits very snugly inside the holder in order to prevent movement. No glue is necessary for this piece, but you may need a padded vice or a small rubber clamp to squeeze it all the way back till it's seated.
Designed in FreeCAD with some basic measurements, trial, and error. Teaching myself as I go.

title: KIBO Prosthetic Hand for Below Elbow Amputation

description.text:
This is KIBO (Japanese : Hope), a 3D Printed Prosthetic Hand with actuators.
It is meant for below-elbow amputation.
Everything better be printed in ABS or stronger for real use, and PLA is okay for education and demonstration.

NOTE : this project only include the hand itself and not yet the required electronics assembly, hence you will need to make them yourself (e.g. Arduino)

You will require :

  • 6x M5x15 screws
  • 1x M3x10 screw
  • 1x M3x15 screw
  • 2x 605zz bearings
  • 1x 5mm shaft , 70mm length
  • 1x 5mm shaft , 60mm length
  • 1x 5mm shaft , 50mm length
  • 2x MG996 Servo

Instructions for assembly will be coming soon in video format. Stay tuned!

I designed this for a friend in need, who wanted a hand prosthetic that looks awesome. This project was sized for him, and thus no other sizing is available.

You can contact me directly if you need other sizes or design.

remixed_from.author: FaberUnserzeit
remixed_from.title: customizable round box with threaded lid

description.text:
This is a case for Silicon Lab's Sensor Puck board

See Sensor Puck

I am using this board with my own custom firmware, normally the Puck broadcasts sensor info once per second, and the battery lasts a few days (maybe a week). My firmware modifies this to once per minute (and disables the LED after 60 seconds), so the battery lasts about 4 months (depending on how cold it is). If you are interested, I can share this firmware, but the mods from the base firmware are simple (if you know how to program Silabs boards).

I've designed this to use the sensors of the board outdoors. Note, the CR2032 battery stops working if the ambient temperature drops below -20C (I think the battery freezes). You don't want to know how I know this. Haven't tried it in the summer yet.

Features:

  • Venting hole above the temperature/humidity sensors. The holes are going upwards to the sensor to avoid water getting in, so the tag goes at the top.
  • 5.3mm hole above the light sensor
  • Drain holes at the bottom to remove water possibly getting into the case and to let air circulate.
  • Hole for On/Off switch

The board snaps onto the supports in the lid, and is held in place by friction. The top then screws onto the base, tightening until the light sensor aligns with the tab. Do not over-tighten.

Battery is replaceable if the board is mounted in the case just by removing the top, and levering the board out slightly, but the JTAG port is only accessible by removing the board from the case.

I recommend removing the rubber feet that come on the board (they just pull off), but you can leave them on, it will fit. Sometimes the rubber feet overhang the edge of the board, and this can make it hard to screw the top on (so adjust/remove them).

There is a tall and a short version of the bottom, this makes no difference to the internal space, just gives more thickness to the base (more insulation).

Update: 16/2/2018
I have added a new base with room for a 1/2AA size battery. I used a battery holder https://www.mouser.com/ds/2/209/EPD-200505-1171181.pdf
and an 14250 lithium battery (1200mAh) which is good for cold temperatures, and should last about 1 year (advertising once per minute).

You have to be careful about the wire routing, as it will get tangled when you screw the lid on. I removed the rubber feet to help with this.

Don't forget to remove the coin cell! you can't have two batteries connected at the same time.

Sindoh 3DWOX D200

Notes:

This was printed in White PLA, with rafts, but I'm not sure rafts matter.

I didn't have to do anything, it just worked for me. The original screw top box design reccommends:

put abrasive (scrubbing) powder onto the wet thread and start screwing back and forth and feel the movement becoming easier.
apply a very little bit of linseed or olive oil to the thread

But as I say, I didn't do any of this.

This was based on "customizable round box with threaded lid" as I indicated, modified for the Sensor Puck dimensions. The scad file for the correct dimensions is included, if you want to remix this, but this is just the basic shape (and is not my code, so it's in German I think)).

The rest of the design was added on from the Sensor Puck dimensions (measured very inaccurately by me).

I suggest that you read the original design notes for the box before you change anything.

A sword letter opener. The sword in just over seven inches long.
Print, glue and touch up as required.

remixed_from.title: X Belt tensioner for Tevo Tarantula

title: Belt tensioners for Tevo Tarantula - hex

description.text:
Downloaded Banholms belt tensioners (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1704100 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1730521) and really liked them. Except that it was designed to pressure fit round boltheads into the tensioners. I figured that it would've been better to have it designed for a hex bolt, and after reading some comments it was clear that I wasn't the only one who had this thought.
So here's a remix of the tensioner modules but with slots for hex boltheads. I also threw in a turnwheel to hold a hexnut.

2x m4x40 hex bolt
2x m4 hex nut (preferably a locknut)
Usage is the same as Banholms original, you could just be a little more sure that the bolts won't turn as you tighten the belts

comments.text: Bonjour, excellent travail. J'ai un problème pour imprimer la première étape parce que ce n'est pas conforme au plan et que les crochets n'aident pas. Devrais-je faire une compensation x / y pour imprimer les écrous et les boulons?
comments.author: Marcorelio

comments.text:
Merci bonjour
Sur quelle pièce avez-vous un problème?
Normalement il n'y a pas besoin de compenser.
Réglez peut être votre température.
Tenez moi au courant.
Bonne journée
comments.author: Marcorelio

comments.text: Dans la première jambe. Cette pièce n'a pas la base affleurant le plan de la table et quand elle arrive au bord gauche l'impression est faite dans l'air. J'ai réussi à améliorer un peu, y compris une couche de radeau, mais il est difficile de nettoyer la pièce plus tard. En tout cas, c'est un excellent travail. Je vais le présenter à mes filles. Merci.

comments.text:
Bonjour, pour les vis et écrous 100 %, pour les autres pièces 60%. Faut pas être pressés. Ne pas hésiter à doubler les pièces sur plateau pour laisser le temps de refroidir, pour la vis M8 par exemple.
Il faut faire des essais.
Bonne impression
